pgTitle: Timeline of the introduction of color television in countries

rows.text: First transmission was the Eurovision broadcast of New Year Concert from Vienna on January 1, 1969. Full-time color transmissions since January 15, 1975.
ZBM was an affiliate of the U.S. network CBS.
Full-time color transmissions started in 1985. Last country in Asia with black and white transmission to introduce color television.
First color broadcasts came from Moscow; first local color program was transmitted on December 30, 1972. Transistioned from SECAM to PAL 1992-1999.
First Central American country to introduce color television.
KUAM was a primary NBC affiliate that also carried some programming from ABC and CBS.
Broadcast continued in black-and-white until the late 1980s.
Full-time color broadcasts began on 24 August 1980.
The first Asian country to introduce color television, on September 10, 1960.
Test color broadcasts began in 1975. Full-time color broadcasts since 1981.
Experimental color broadcast for the 1980 Summer Olympics.
First color broadcasts came from Moscow. First local color program was transmitted on January 28, 1974. Switched from SECAM to PAL on February 2, 1998.
Color television arrived on a full-time schedule in 1978.
Introduced on both national channels on September 21, 1967.
The first color broadcast was the speech made by the King on December 31, 1971. Full-time color broadcasts since 1975. Color broadcasts had been available from Sweden since 1970.

First color test transmission was in 1963. Commercial launch in June 1966 using RCA color; and full-time color transmissions began in 1971 when color sets became more widespread in the Manila area and suburbs.
Broadcasts in the rural areas continued in black-and-white until late 1980s.
Full-time color broadcasts began on 1 November 1977.
Test transmissions started on December 14, 1966. Regular color service and color license fee introduced April 1, 1970.
Color transmission had been available from France and Germany since 1967.
Experimental color broadcast for the 1980 Summer Olympics.

Although television in Thailand originally employed a 525-line screen (System M, US standard at the time), the country opted for PAL color, which necessitated a conversion to system B (625 lines), starting with Channel 7 in November 1967. Regional stations converted between 1972 and 1975.
Dot sequential system. The United States gradually transitioned from black-and-white to color television between 1953 and 1968.
KHVH was an ABC affiliate, KGMB was CBS, and KONA was NBC.
Introduced specifically for the 50th Golden Jubilee Anniversary of the October Revolution. Full-time colorcasts began with the Revolution's 58th anniversary, in 1975.
Experimental color broadcast for the 1980 Summer Olympics.
Color television arrived on a full-time schedule in 1979.
Color broadcasts had been available from North Yemen since 1979.
The last country with black and white transmission to introduce color television.
